I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The proposed capacity development technical assistance (TA) is consistent with the 
South Asia regional cooperation strategy, 2011–2015 and the Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
country partnership strategy for Nepal, 2010–2012, both of which accord high priority to regional 
connectivity and trade facilitation. It was conceptualized following consultations conducted for 
South Asia Subregional Economic Cooperation (SASEC) trade facilitation during October 2012–
March 2013. It was also included in the South Asia regional cooperation operations business 
plan, 2013-2015.1 
2.  At meetings of the SASEC trade facilitation and transport working groups (TFTWG) in 
2010–2012, the governments of SASEC countries requested continued support from ADB for 
the  SASEC  trade  facilitation.2 At  the  SASEC  TFTWG  meeting  in  Thimphu,  Bhutan,  on  8 
November  2012,  SASEC  country  delegations  (i)  agreed  to  expand  assistance  to  trade 
facilitation through additional TA to provide full support to ongoing initiatives and (ii) requested 
ADB to explore the possibility of providing TA to respond to the trade facilitation needs of 
SASEC countries. All consulted parties agreed broadly on the expected impacts and outcomes 
of the TA and strongly support TA design and  proposed implementation. The design and 
monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.3  
II.  ISSUES 
3.  According  to  the World  Bank  Doing  Business  reports,  2006–2013,  Nepal  does  not 
facilitate trade well.4 The country’s rank fell from 136 in 2007 to 171 in 2012. Nepal’s key trade 
facilitation  indicators  underperform  the  average  in  South  Asia.  The  weak  performance  is 
attributed to a number of key factors. 
4.  Large number of trade documents. Preparing documents takes considerable time and 
constitutes a major barrier to trade facilitation. In 2012, it took 11 documents and 41 days to 
complete normal export processing, at a cost of $1,975 per container. It took 11 documents and 
38 days to complete normal import processing, at a cost of $2,095 per container. In addition, 
Nepal  has  yet  to  conform  to  accepted  standards  of  trade  documentation  specified  in  the 
International  Convention  on  the  Simplification  and  Harmonization  of  Customs  Procedures, 
otherwise known as the Revised Kyoto Convention (RKC).  
5.  Inadequate  customs  automation.  Nepal currently uses the Automated System for 
Customs Data ++ for customs operations at 15 major customs offices and applies risk-based 
customs clearance at six major customs offices. However, the customs process is not fully 
automated, and technical difficulties affect system operation. In addition, the current Informix 
database is obsolete and needs to be migrated to a new system. Nepal needs a master plan for 
e-customs and customs automation. Currently, 70%–90% of cargoes are inspected at border 
checkpoints. Risk-based inspection is generally not applied, except in a limited way at six land 
border crossings. Most cargo must be physically inspected for lack of modern equipment to 
support the border clearance procedures.   
6.  Lack of transparency and publicly available trade and custom-related rules. This 
lack is a nontariff barrier to trade with Nepal. Priorities of Nepal’s private sector regarding trade

facilitation are therefore the timely and comprehensive publication of trade and custom rules 
and regulations, and their effective and transparent application. 
 
7.  Other behind border barriers. Other issues such as quarantine testing, clearing and 
freight forwarding, insurance, terminal handling, and port services are critical nontariff barriers to 
trade  in  Nepal.  It  is  therefore  important  to  comprehensively  assess  and  streamline  these 
nontariff barriers. 
8.  Nepal  has  taken  several  initiatives  to  facilitate  trade  such  as  applying  harmonized 
system codes for customs tariffs, adopting the World Trade Organization Customs Valuation 
Agreement, enacting the new Customs Act and associated rules and regulations, establishing 
the Automated System for Customs Data ++ for clearance at 15 major customs offices, and 
introducing risk-based customs clearance at six major customs offices. Nepal has constructed 
an inland container deport at Kakarbhitta, supported by an ADB loan. 
9.  Nepal actively participates in the SASEC TFTWG. Through the TFTWG, Nepal is taking 
part in an ADB-supported subregional trade facilitation program along with Bangladesh and 
Bhutan. 1 The components of the program grant to Nepal include the following:  
(i)  Supporting modern and effective customs administration. ADB is helping 
Nepal (as well as Bangladesh and Bhutan) accede to the RKC, comply with its 
provisions,  and  apply  the  Framework  of  Standards  to  Secure  and  Facilitate 
Global Trade.  
(ii)  Streamlining regulations and procedures. ADB’s support enhances Nepal’s 
automated customs management systems, which is important for establishing a 
national single window.  
(iii)  Improving  services  and  information  for  traders  and  investors.  ADB  is 
helping SASEC governments implement reforms that will inform and respond to 
importers and exporters more effectively, notably through electronic trade portals 
and the establishment of national trade facilitation committees. 
Initial experience in implementing the program in Nepal suggests that the government needs 
assistance in ensuring that these components are achieved, and in putting in place other key 
legal, regulatory, and institutional and capacity requirements for customs modernization and 
reforms.2 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
10.  The expected impact of the TA is Nepal enjoying speedier and less costly trade, to be 
indicated  by  the  time  it  takes to  export  and  import. The  expected  outcome  will  be  better 
alignment  of  Nepalese  customs’  procedures  and  practices  with  internationally  accepted 
standards. 
 
                                                
1  ADB approved in November 2012 SASEC Trade Facilitation Program loans and grants to Bangladesh, Bhutan, and 
Nepal to help develop modern customs administrations, streamline regulations and procedures, and provide 
improved services and information to traders. 
2  Bangladesh and Bhutan are also in need of resources and capacity to put into effect the reforms being promoted 
under  the  SASEC  Trade  Facilitation  Program  loans  and  grants.  CDTA  support  is  also  being  planned  for 
Bangladesh and Bhutan.

3  
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.  The TA will have five planned outputs: (i) consensus reached to accede to the RKC; (ii) 
effective operation of the automated customs management system; (iii) client service centers 
established; (iv) Customs Information Portal established, and (v) agreed business plan for the 
Four-Year Customs Reform and Modernization Strategy and Action Plan, 2013–2017.  
12.  Consensus Reached to Accede to the Revised Kyoto Convention. The TA will help 
the Government of Nepal to assess the regulatory impact of proposed amendments to laws and 
regulations.  To  complement  regulatory  reform  related  to  RKC  accession,  the  TA  will  also 
support activities to raise key stakeholders’ awareness of the RKC, in collaboration with the 
World Customs Organization (WCO).  
13.  Effective operation of the automated customs management system. The TA will 
help provide technical training to Nepalese customs officials on issues related to customs 
automation and a national single window. 
14.  Client  service  centers  established. The TA will support establishing client service 
centers at selected border points to facilitate information sharing and other interaction between 
border agencies and traders.  
15.  Customs  Information  Portal  established.  Information  on  trade  and  customs 
regulations is critical for trade facilitation. The TA will help Nepal share accurate and detailed 
information on trade- and customs-related laws, regulations, procedures, and documentation. 
These documents will be made publically available in Nepal’s Customs Information Portal.  
16.  Agreed  business  plan  for  the  Four-Year  Customs  Reform  and  Modernization 
Strategy and Action Plan. Nepal’s Four-Year Customs Reform and Modernization Strategy 
and Action Plan, 2013–2017 has been approved. The strategy identifies priority activities to be 
supported  and  implemented  with  possible  support  from  other  development  partners.  It  is 
therefore important for the Nepal Department of Customs to develop a business plan that 
includes resource mobilization and the implementation of priority activities.  
C.  Cost and Financing 
17.  The TA is estimated to cost $1.6 million, of which $1.5 million will be financed on a grant 
basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction, and administered by ADB. The government will 
provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff and office accommodation, and 
other in-kind contributions.  The detailed cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2.  
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
18.  The TA will be implemented over 24 months from September 2013 to August 2015. The 
ADB  South  Asia  Department  will  be  the  executing  agency  and  the  Nepal  Department  of 
Customs the implementing agency. ADB will work closely with the WCO and other international 
organizations,  such  as  the  Economic  and  Social  Commission  for  Asia  and  the  Pacific,  in 
implementing the TA, particularly for activities under outputs 1 and 2.  
19.  On 25 January 2013, the South Asia Regional Cooperation and Operations Coordination 
Division, the executing agency’s focal point for the TA, and the WCO Asia Pacific Regional

4   
Office for Capacity Building met in Bangkok for a 1-day planning retreat.1 The ADB mission and 
the WCO agreed on six themes for capacity building: general annex provisions of the RKC, the 
SAFE Framework of Standards to Secure and Facilitate Global Trade (SAFE Framework), 
authorized  economic  operators,  risk  management,  post  clearance  audit,  and  time  release 
study2.  
20.  Building on a training needs assessment workshop on 28 March 2013, the following 
training workshops have been identified for 2013: (i) a regional knowledge-sharing workshop; (ii) 
a  regional  workshop  on  the  WCO  compendium  on  national  single  windows  for  SASEC 
countries, Sri Lanka, and the Maldives; and (iii) a regional workshop on a time release study for 
Bangladesh, Bhutan, and Nepal. WCO officials will share their semiannual capacity-building 
programs with the South Asia Regional Coordinating and Country Division on a regular basis to 
better synchronize the training programs of both institutions. 
21.  The TA will require 58.5 person-months of international consultancy and 96 person-
months of national consultancy, consisting of (i) 27 person-months each from international 
customs and trade facilitation specialists; (ii) 36 person-months each from legal and trade 
facilitation specialists; (iii) 24 person-months from web and content managers; and (iv) 4.5 
person-months from resource persons who will participate in capacity building on international 
best practice, coordinating development partner activities and trade facilitation, and supporting 
the preparation of a regulatory impact study. Consultants will be engaged by ADB as individuals 
in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2013, as amended from time 
to time). The outline terms of reference for consultants are in Appendix 3. All procurement and 
disbursements under the TA will follow ADB Procurement Guidelines (2013, as amended from 
time to time) and the Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from 
time to time).  
22.  The TA will be monitored and coordinated principally through meetings of the SASEC 
TFTWG and the SASEC customs subgroup, as well as through national and regional meetings 
held under TA auspices.3 TA outputs will be evaluated by the South Asia Department through 
annual TA implementation review missions, assisted by the Nepal Resident Mission.  
23.  Best practices and lessons from the TA will be documented in the progress reports 
submitted to the SASEC TFTWG and posted on the SASEC website (www.sasec.asia). Good 
practices  and  lessons  learned  will  also  be  reported  during  meetings  of  ADB’s  Regional 
Cooperation and Integration Community of Practice. 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
 
25.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering  technical  assistance  not  exceeding  the  equivalent  of  $1,500,000  to  the 
Government of Nepal to be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction 
for  Supporting  Participation  in  the  South  Asia  Subregional  Economic  Cooperation  Trade 
Facilitation Program, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

Directorate of the WCO Secretariat, joined the retreat by teleconference.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  Under  the  supervision  of  the  South  Asia  Department  team  overseeing  technical 
assistance (TA) implementation, a team of individual international and national consultants will 
be  engaged.  In  addition,  international  resource  persons  will  support  capacity  building  by 
participating in workshops and training programs, as well as guide the development of programs 
and reports. An estimated 154.5 person-months of consulting services (58.5 person-months 
international and 96 national) will be required over 24 months. The indicative person-month 
allocations and outline terms of reference for the consultants are as follows. 
 
A.  International Consultants 
 
1.  Customs specialists (27 person-months combined, intermittent).  
 
2.  Analytical work. Tasks will include the following: 
(i)  Undertake analytical work to identify gaps between the existing situation in Nepal 
and key international standards such as those of the Revised Kyoto Convention 
(RKC) and the World Trade Organization (WTO) Agreement on Valuation and 
Rules of Origin, in particular the benchmarks set out in the RKC and the SAFE 
Framework of Standards, and identify Nepalese laws, regulations, procedures, 
and forms that can be harmonized. 
(ii)  Examine, through supply and demand analysis using qualitative and quantitative 
tools, the feasibility of introducing effective post-clearance and/or post-release 
controls (an important function of customs in trade facilitation) and associated 
simplified import and export procedures, based upon sound risk management 
principles for Nepal’s customs administration.  
(iii)  Prepare working papers and other publications and provide other inputs related 
to customs. 
(iv)  Propose  concrete  projects  such  as  loans  and  capacity  building  technical 
assistance projects in line with the analysis. 
 
3.  Policy support. Tasks will include the following: 
(i)  Support the preparation of an e-customs master plan, which will include a time-
bound  implementation  plan  to  upgrade  its  automated  customs  management 
system and integrate customs operations. 
(ii)  Assist in establishing a national single window program that will (a) specify the 
lead  agency  and  other  participating  agencies,  (b)  outline  the  roles  and 
responsibilities of participating agencies, and (c) provide an implementation plan 
toward launching a pilot national single window program. 
(iii)  Assist  the  preparation  of  a  directive  supporting  the  participation  of  the 
Department of Customs in the national single window program and appropriating 
resources for the Department of Customs involvement as recommended by the 
e-customs master plan. 
(iv)  Assist in establishing client service centers at selected customs border posts. 
(v)  Participate in trade facilitation and transport working group meetings as technical 
experts presenting analytical findings from field work. 
(vi)  Provide technical support for the preparation of a business plan for the Four-Year 
Customs Reform and Modernization Strategy and Action Plan. 
(vii)  Assist  the  Department  of  Customs  of  Nepal  in  updating  and  monitoring  the 
implementation of the Four-Year Customs Reform and Modernization Strategy 
and Action Plan.

10        Appendix 3         
(viii)     Assist the Department of Customs of Nepal in administering the operations of the   
  client service centers. 
 
4.  Capacity building. The specialists will assess the training needs and organize and 
deliver targeted training programs for Nepal’s customs officials on the RKC, SAFE framework, 
and other issues related to custom operations and procedures. 
 
5.  Qualifications. The consultants will have the following qualifications:  
(i)  A master’s or similar degree in international law, economics, international trade, 
public policy, or a related area.  
(ii)  At least 10 years of work experience in and knowledge of the full range of 
customs  procedures  and  operations,  as  well  as  institutional  experience  in 
applying them operationally.  
(iii)  Considerable practical experience on issues related to the RKC and the SAFE 
framework.  
(iv)  Proven  skills  in  writing  policy  reports  and  papers  and  expertise  in  training 
government officials.  
(v)  Experience of working in and/or for the Asian Development Bank (ADB), United 
Nations  Economic  and  Social  Commission  for  Asia  and  the  Pacific,  World 
Customs  Organization  (WCO),  World  Trade  Organization,  United  Nations 
Conference on Trade and Development, and World Bank on issues related to 
trade facilitation is highly desirable. 
(i)  Similar work experience in South Asia would be a distinct advantage.  
(vi)  Proven skills in project design are desirable. 
 
2.  Trade facilitation specialists (27 person-months combined, intermittent).  
 
6.  Analytical work. Tasks will include the following: 
(i)  Analyze the trends, challenges, and prospects of trade facilitation in Nepal. 
(ii)  Review  and  consider  regional  and  international  experience  relevant  to  trade 
facilitation in Nepal. 
(iii)  Conduct in-depth assessments of trade facilitation in Nepal, including the use of 
a time release methodology to determine the cost and time required to trade 
along  priority  transport  corridors  such  as  Birgunj–Kolkata  and  Karkavita–
Chittagong. 
(iv)  Examine key elements of trade facilitation such as customs, quarantine testing, 
clearing and freight forwarding, insurance, terminal handling, and port services 
as they affect domestic and international road, rail, and air transport in Nepal. 
(v)  Identify  behind-border trade facilitation  and  logistic  impediments  in  Nepal  by 
assessing  logistic  development,  including  multimodal  facilities  and/or 
interchanges, freight distribution centers, container depots, and service providers 
along such high-priority corridors as Birgunj–Kolkata and Kakavirta–Chittagong. 
(vi)  Assess the economic potential of key transport corridors and the possibility of 
developing industrial zones or special economic zones along these corridors. 
(vii)  Assess issues related to Nepal’s transit trade, including those related to bilateral 
transit agreements between Nepal and India.  
(viii)  Document supply chain costs for Nepal’s intra- and inter-regional trade, including 
transaction costs at various points in a trade transaction or flow. 
(ix)  Prepare working papers and other publications and other inputs related to trade 
facilitation.

associated policy actions for the follow-on investment program and/or projects of 
the recently approved South Asia Subregional Economic Cooperation (SASEC) 
Trade Facilitation Program. 
(xi)  Propose concrete projects such as loans and capacity building technical 
assistance projects in line with the analysis. 
 
7.  Policy support. Tasks will include the following:  
(i)  Formulate proposals for strategies, policies, and programs as well as effective 
measures to harmonize legislation with trade facilitation in Nepal.  
(ii)  Recommend possible legal, regulatory, and operational frameworks, and identify 
possible routes and centers for further developing trade logistics in Nepal. 
(iii)  Identify areas of high trade-facilitation costs in Nepal to establish where 
investment or reform may be most effective, and sequence and prioritize the 
reform program.  
(iv)  Participate in SASEC trade facilitation and transport working group meetings as 
technical experts presenting analytical findings from field work. 
 
8.  Capacity Building. The specialists will assess training needs and organize and deliver 
targeted training programs for Nepalese officials. 
 
9.  Qualifications. The consultants will have the following qualifications:
